Ian,

One of the interesting things that comes up when you're working with 
evolution is how much you should allow your own analytic intuitions 
to constrain the final solution.  You've put a lot of thought into 
the way modularity could work, but one question I have is how much 
of this architecture will just naturally arise out of the right kind 
of encoding and evolutionary algorithm on its own?  The other side 
of the question is that there may be a better way to think about 
this that evolution might discover, but it won't discover it if you 
predetermine what the right way to do things is.  That's not in any 
way a criticism of what you've been talking about.  Rather, it's 
just to point out that it's sometimes hard to know how much thought 
we should be putting into the solution itself as opposed to a system 
that can automatically generate the solution on its own.  It's a 
sublte and confusing distinction sometimes.

I also agree with Mitchell in that we really need some problems that 
require the kinds of complex architectures that we are speculating 
about.  It's surprisingly hard to think of good benchmarks that need 
or utilize modularity explicitly, or that utilize any kind of high-
level complexity for that matter.  What kind of problem would 
require an NN with a million neurons, but wouldn't take 300 years to 
solve?  In other words, what's the right simple proof of concept to 
show that you can evolve something complex?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> Hi,
> 	I've been spouting this idea that a modular evolving system 
(NEAT or 
> otherwise) would have to define (and eventually evolve) the 
interfaces 
> between the modules for quite a while now, and I'm curious to know 
whether 
> people have any opinions on the approach, e.g. good, bad, 
indifferent, or 
> you just don't get it?
> 
> 	Ian
> 
> 
> Living@Home - Open Source Evolving Organisms -
